Implemented file types¶

Here importing of different file-types (ftypes) is discussed.

RockPy.core¶

class RockPy.core.ftype.Ftype(dfile, snames=None, dialect=None, reload=False, create_minfo=True, mdata=None, **kwargs)¶

Delivers core functionality to all classes inheriting from it.

in_units¶

units from used in the data file

Type

dict(pint.ureg)

out_units¶

units used to export the data

Type

dict(pint.ureg)

units¶

units used internally (should be SI units)

Type

dict(pint.ureg)

fid¶

internal id of the instance

Type

int

_raw_data¶

raw, imported data from the file. Note: has not been converted to SI units.

Type

list(str)

snames¶

tuple of all names in the datafile

Type

tuple(str)

dfile¶

full path to the file on the HD

Type

str

dialect¶

can change the behavior of the Ftype.read_file method

Type

str, optional

header¶

header data generated from the data file. May not exist for certain ftypes

Type

pandas.DataFrame, optional

importhelper¶

Object that helps importing files using the RockPy naming convention. Only created if create_minfo is True

Type

RockPy.core.file_io.ImportHelper, optional

file_infos¶

Information on the file. Only created if create_minfo = True

Type

dict, optional

imported_files¶

Secondary storage of a deepcopy of the obj.data, for possible recovery.

Type

dict

Notes

The units that the data is stored in are SI units. They can be converted using RockPy.core.utils.convert.

property raw_data¶

raw data of the file.

If _raw_data is None (initialized in constructor, read_raw_data is called and assigned to _raw_data.

read_file()¶

Method for actual import of the file.

This method needs to be written for each filetype. It is called in the __init__ constructor.

See also

The read_file methods of classes inheriting from Ftype

reads file from HD.

Reads the file from HD using:
>>> with open(dfile, 'r', encoding="ascii", errors="surrogateescape") as f:

Returns

the data read with encoding = ‘asci’, and errors = ‘surrogateescape’

rename_file_using_RockPy_convention(backup=True)¶

Renames the file using the NEW RockPy naming convention.

The function tries to create the new style RockPy file name from the internal file infos. By default it creates a copy of the original file, that is commented by using ‘#’ in from of the name.

RockPy.ftype.cif¶

class RockPy.ftypes.cif.Cif(dfile, snames=None, reload=False, mdata=None, create_minfo=True, level_unit='gauss', dialect=None, **kwargs)¶

Ftype object that contains data read in from ‘cif’ files.

data¶

Data contained in the cif (or. UP) files. Note: units are converted to SI internally

Type

pandas.DataFrame

corrections¶

A dictionary of the dec, inc values for all possible orientations (below, towards) when measuring in the UP position.

Type

dict

in_units¶

units from used in the data file

Type

dict(pint.ureg)

out_units¶

units used to export the data

Type

dict(pint.ureg)

units¶

units used internally (should be SI units)

Type

dict(pint.ureg)

datacolumns¶

names of all the columns should be the same as self.data.columns

Type

tuple(str)

Notes

Data columns:
`’mtype’, ‘level’, ‘geo_dec’, ‘geo_inc’, ‘strat_dec’, ‘strat_inc’, ‘intensity’, ‘ang_err’,

‘plate_dec’, ‘plate_inc’, ‘std_x’, ‘std_y’, ‘std_z’, ‘user’, ‘date’, ‘time’`

See also

For more information on attributes see RockPy.core.ftype.Ftype

classmethod _add_missing_levels(data)¶

Adds the correct level for a UAFX measurement.

Adds the correct level for a UAFX measurement, assuming it is the same level as the previous AF measurement.

Returns

with a additional column ‘old_levels’

Return type

pandas.Dataframe

Warning

Assuming that the previous AF step is the same as the UAFX steps, may be wrong.

classmethod _mean_levels(df, core_dip, core_strike, strat_dip, strat_strike)¶

Calculates mean of AF, UAFX … measurement with the same level.

Calculates the average for (AF, UAFX1, UAFX2, …) of the same level. Recalcuates the plate, core and strat declination and inclinations.

Parameters

  • df (pandas.DataFrame) – data with AF, UAFX … measurements

  • core_dip (float) – Dip of the core

  • core_strike (float) – Strike of the core

  • strat_dip (float) – Stratigraphic dip

  • strat_strike (float) – Stratigraphic strike

Returns

averaged data with recalculated geographic and stratigraphic (dec, inc) values

Return type

pandas.Series

Notes

Is called by `mean_levels’ resets self.data with the means.

classmethod _read_UP_file(dfile, sample_id, reload=False)¶

Read function for Up files.

This function reads in the UP file and returns a pandas.DataFrame with the data in SI units.

Parameters

  • dfile (str) – full path of the file on HD

  • sample_id (str) – In case more than one sample is in the file, this filters for the right sample

  • reload (bool) – defaults to False. If True the file will be reloaded. If False the file will be read only from the cached copy in RockPy.ftype.cif.Cif.imported_files[dfile].

Returns

in SI units

Return type

pandas.DataFrame

classmethod _read_header(header_rows)¶

Reads the header of a cif file.

In the first line the first four characters are the locality id, the next 9 the sample id, and the remainder (to 255) is a sample comment.

In the second line, the first character is ignored, the next 6 comprise the stratigraphic level (usually in meters). The remaining fields are all the same format: first character ignored (should be a blank space) and then 5 characters used. These are the core strike, core dip, bedding strike, bedding dip, and core volume or mass. Conventions are discussed below. CIT format can include fold axis and plunge, which at present is unused.

Parameters

header_rows (list(str)) – List of str from the read_file method.

classmethod _read_raw_UP_file(dfile)¶

Reads the raw UP file and formats the values

Parameters

dfile (str) – full path to file on HD

Returns

Dataframe with raw_data

Return type

pandas.DataFrame

static _return_mean_from_UP_file(df)¶

takes a DataFrame created from reading in an (UP) file (see. read_UP_files)

This method subtracts the holder measurements and calculates the mean from the 4 measurement positions. It returns a new pandas.DataFrame with the data.

Parameters

df (pandas.DataFrame) – with the raw data.

classmethod _rotate_UP_measurements(sdata)¶

Rotates the 2,3,4 measurement of an UP file so they align with the 1st.

Due to the sample handler rotation, the raw data of the 2,3, and 4 th positions in the UP file are rotated. This method rotates 2,3,4 into the same orientation as 1.

Parameters

sdata (pandas.DataFrame) – The unrotated data

Returns

The rotated data

Return type

sdata (pandas.DataFrame)

Notes

  • For some reason, the y component has to be multiplied by -1. Otherwise the values from the UP files and the cif file generated by the rapid system are not the same.

  • If the measurement direction is ‘DOWN’ instead of up, y and z values are multiplied by -1

static _separate_row(raw_data)¶

Strips each line of the ‘cif’ file into its values.

Parameters

raw_data (list(str)) – List of strings from read_file

Returns:

export(fname, sample_id=None, **kwargs)¶

Exports a cif file from the data :param fname str: where the data should be stored :param sample_id: :type sample_id: name of the sample for the cif file

classmethod from_rapid(files_or_folder, sample_id, locality_id='', core_strike=0.0, core_dip=0.0, bedding_strike=0.0, bedding_dip=0.0, core_volume_or_mass=1, stratigraphic_level='', comment='', user='lancaster', reload=False)¶

reads Up files or folder containing Up-files and constructs a cif-like object.

Parameters

  • files_or_folder (str, list) – if files_or_folder is a folder, all files will be loaded using os.listdir if files_or_folder is a list of files, each file will be loaded

  • sample_id (str) – The name of the sample in the UP files. This is because there may be more than one sample in the files.

  • locality_id (str, optional) – defaults to ‘’. The name of the locality is used for export. It is written in the header of the new sample_id file.

  • core_strike (float, optional) – defaults to 0. Strike of the core with respect to machine coordinates

  • core_dip (float, optional) – defaults to 0. Dip of the core with respect to machine coordinates

  • bedding_strike (float, optional) – defaults to 0. Strike of the bedding plane

  • bedding_dip (float, optional) – defaults to 0. Dip of the bedding plane

  • core_volume_or_mass (float, optional) – defaults to 1. This, again is used for export purposes only. The cif files exported from the rapid system are normalized by either the mass or the volume of the sample, which is given in the file header. Thus it needs to be specified if normalization is desired.

  • stratigraphic_level (float, optional) – defaults to ‘’. Used in export

  • comment (str, optional) – defaults to ‘’. Used in export

  • user (str, optional) – defaults to ‘lancaster’. Used in export

  • reload (bool, optional) – defaults to False. If False, the file will be read every time the from_rapid method is called. If True, a cached version of the file is used, speeding up the code somewhat.

Examples

Creating an object:

>> import RockPy
>> cif_object = RockPy.ftype.cif.Cif.from_rapid(
>>     files_or_folder = "location_of_the_files_on_HD",
>>     sample_id = 'sample',
>>     )

This will now read in all files in the folder, or all specified files (list).

Returns

RockPy.ftype.cif.Cif

property geo_dim¶

Returns pandas.DataFrame of the geographic (dec, inc, intensity)

property geo_xyz¶

Returns pandas.DataFrame of the geographic (x,y,z)

mean_levels()¶

Calculates the mean of a level by from AF, UAFX1, UAFX2… measuements.

Calculates the average for (AF, UAFX1, UAFX2, …) of the same level and recalcuates the plate, core and strat declination and inclinations.

Notes

`_mean_levels’ can be used for testing purposes. This does not reset self.data with the means but returns a copy of the Dataframe.

See also

RockPy.ftypes.cif.Cif._mean_levels()

Returns”

pandas.DataFrame: DataFrame with the mean of the data.

property plate_dim¶

Returns pandas.DataFrame of the plate (dec, inc, intensity)

property plate_xyz¶

Returns pandas.DataFrame of the plate (x,y,z)

read_file()¶

The sample format is illustrated by the following fragment:

>>00000000011111111112222222222333333333344444444445555555555666666666677777777778
>>12345678901234567890123456789012345678901234567890123456789012345678901234567890
>>erb  1.0A    Sample just above tuff
>>  113.0 291.0  63.0  43.0  46.0   1.0
>>NRM     41.2  49.7  91.4  41.0 3.44E-05   5.5 184.1 -13.1  0.0289  0.0270  0.0468
>>TT 150  46.7  41.3  84.3  33.7 1.79E-05   7.5 189.4 -20.9  0.0188  0.0130  0.0228
>>TT 225  55.6  36.8  84.5  25.5 1.44E-05   4.0 197.8 -23.3  0.0193  0.0252  0.0171

It starts with the header rows.

See also

See _read_header

The following lines are in the order the demagnetizations were carried out. The first 2 characters (3 for NRM only) is the demag type (AF for alternating field, TT for thermal, CH for chemical, etc.), the next 4 (3 for NRM) is the demag level (°C for thermal, mT for alternating field, etc.), the next 6 (first blank for all the following fields) for geographic (“in situ”) declination of the sample’s magnetic vector, next 6 for geographic inclination, next 6 for stratigraphic declination, next 6 for stratigraphic inclination, next 9 for normalized intensity (emu/cm^3; multiply by the core volume/mass to get the actual measured core intensity), next 6 for measurement error angle, next 6 for core plate declination, next 6 for core plate inclination, and the final three fields of 8 each are the standard deviations of the measurement in the core’s x, y, and z coordinates in 10^5 emu. NB in 2003, it appears the CIT format is actually using three final fields of 9 characters, not 8.

Presently only the sample id line, the second line, and the first ten fields (to core inclination but excepting the error angle) of the demag lines are used in PaleoMag. Except for the stratigraphic level, info on the second line is only displayed in the info window or used in the “Headers…” command. A possibility exists that future versions will plot Zijder plots with the measurement uncertainties.

Returns

Return type

pd.DataFrame

reset_geo_di(dip=None, strike=None)¶

resets dec and inc in geographic coordinates

Parameters

  • dip (float, optional) – defaults to the stored ‘core_dip’ value. Inclination of the core.

  • strike (float, optional) – defaults to the stored ‘core_strike’ value. Declination of the core.

See also

RockPy.ftypes.cif.Cif._correct_core() for the private method that is called.

uses: RockPy.tools.compute.xyz2dim()

Returns

Data recalculated from x,y,z values

Return type

pandas.DataFrame
